subject: Re: [junit] ANN: test your JUnit 3.8/4.0 skills
msgSnippet: ... I failed my beta test. Enough said, but I want to say more. The answer to the question Test Driven Design (#4387) is laughably wrong. It might suffice

Bradley, Todd wrote:

> I don't know anything about javablackbelt.com, but I
> hope you're not going to charge anyone money to take
> that test as it's currently written!  It tests knowledge
> of things that aren't JUnit, inadequately tests things
> are ARE JUnit, and considers opinions as facts.  Plus,
> many of the questions are posed in such weak English
> that they are ambiguous and confusing.  Or maybe to be
> a "Java Black Belt" you must surpass such trivia.

I failed my beta test. Enough said, but I want to say more.

The answer to the question "Test Driven Design" (#4387) is laughably 
wrong. It might suffice for a beginner practitioner, but otherwise it's 
woefully inadequate.

The answer to question #4383 (throwing exceptions) is absurd, since 
there's no indication which conditions of the call to doOperation() 
might throw which exception. The explanation is one person's opinion, 
and misses the point:

"The only way to test properly that certain exceptions have been thrown 
is using variables. When more than one exception may be thrown, then it 
becomes hard to understand the code if it simple says 'fail'."

This is only true if you're trying to test for different expected 
exceptions in the same test. Who the hell does that?!

It doesn't serve the community to project oneself as authoritative when 
there is obvious literature out there that contradicts the answers to 
this questions. For such a quiz, stick to answers that can be verified 
by running code and leave the opinion stuff out.

Take care.
-- 
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger :: http://www.jbrains.info
